site_name: Alaska Airlines - LAX - Los Angeles International Airport

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
On May 25, 2025, a female 8-month-old intact German shepherd, MC#981098108630650, was transported on Alaska
Airlines flight AS1351 originating from Costa Rica to Los Angeles airport (LAX) ( AWB 27-72840821). The dog arrived at
approximately 6:15 am and was held by the airline, due to transfer paperwork, for over 11 hours before it was transferred
to an animal care facility (ACF). The Center for Disease Control (CDC) reports, the enclosure did not have sufficient litter
provided to absorb excreta as required. Documents provided show there appeared to be a paper product torn in pieces
and soaked by excreta with urine pooled in the bottom of the transport enclosure. The condition of the crate and the
inability for the dog to get away from the animal waste may have led to her discomfort and distress. The primary transport
enclosure must contain enough previously unused litter to absorb and cover excreta. The litter must be of a suitably
absorbent material that is safe and non-toxic to dogs.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
On May 25, 2025, a female 8-month-old intact German shepherd, MC#981098108630650, was transported on Alaska
Airlines flight AS1351 originating from Costa Rica to Los Angeles airport (LAX) ( AWB 27-72840821). The dog arrived at
approximately 6:15 am and was held by the airline, due to transfer paperwork, for over 11 hours before it was transferred
to an animal care facility (ACF). The CDC reports the enclosure used to transport the dog was not large enough for the
dog to make normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement. The documents provided show
the dog was taller than the transport crate and could not stand up with her head upright, which may have led to her
discomfort and distress. Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs must be large enough to ensure that each animal
contained in the primary enclosure has enough space to turn about normally while standing, to stand and sit erect, and to
lie in a natural position.

On May 25, 2025, a female 8-month-old intact German shepherd, MC#981098108630650, was transported on Alaska
Airlines flight AS1351 originating from Costa Rica to Los Angeles airport (LAX) ( AWB 27-72840821). The dog arrived at
approximately 6:15 am and was held by the airline, due to transfer paperwork, for over 11 hours before it was transferred
to an animal care facility (ACF). Although there were feeding instructions provided for the dog, The CDC reports there
were no food or water receptacles present. Failure to provide food and water during transport may lead to dehydration
and other health related conditions, and distress to the animals. Food and water receptacles must be securely attached
inside the primary enclosure and placed so that the receptacles can be filled from outside the enclosure without opening
the door.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.15(a)(9) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats. 
On May 25, 2025, a female 8-month-old intact German shepherd, MC#981098108630650, was transported on Alaska 
Airlines flight AS1351 originating from Costa Rica to Los Angeles airport (LAX) ( AWB 27-72840821). The dog arrived at 
approximately 6:15 am and was held by the airline, due to transfer paperwork, for over 11 hours before it was transferred 
to an animal care facility (ACF). The Center for Disease Control (CDC) reports, the enclosure did not have sufficient litter 
provided to absorb excreta as required. Documents provided show there appeared to be a paper product torn in pieces 
and soaked by excreta with urine pooled in the bottom of the transport enclosure. The condition of the crate and the 
inability for the dog to get away from the animal waste may have led to her discomfort and distress. The primary transport 
enclosure must contain enough previously unused litter to absorb and cover excreta. The litter must be of a suitably 
absorbent material that is safe and non-toxic to dogs. 
3.15(e)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats. 
On May 25, 2025, a female 8-month-old intact German shepherd, MC#981098108630650, was transported on Alaska 
Airlines flight AS1351 originating from Costa Rica to Los Angeles airport (LAX) ( AWB 27-72840821). The dog arrived at 
approximately 6:15 am and was held by the airline, due to transfer paperwork, for over 11 hours before it was transferred 
to an animal care facility (ACF). The CDC reports the enclosure used to transport the dog was not large enough for the 
dog to make normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement. The documents provided show 
the dog was taller than the transport crate and could not stand up with her head upright, which may have led to her 
discomfort and distress. Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs must be large enough to ensure that each animal 
contained in the primary enclosure has enough space to turn about normally while standing, to stand and sit erect, and to 
lie in a natural position. 
3.17(c) 
   
Food and water requirements. 
On May 25, 2025, a female 8-month-old intact German shepherd, MC#981098108630650, was transported on Alaska 
Airlines flight AS1351 originating from Costa Rica to Los Angeles airport (LAX) ( AWB 27-72840821). The dog arrived at 
approximately 6:15 am and was held by the airline, due to transfer paperwork, for over 11 hours before it was transferred

to an animal care facility (ACF). Although there were feeding instructions provided for the dog, The CDC reports there 
were no food or water receptacles present. Failure to provide food and water during transport may lead to dehydration 
and other health related conditions, and distress to the animals. Food and water receptacles must be securely attached 
inside the primary enclosure and placed so that the receptacles can be filled from outside the enclosure without opening 
the door. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
